Hello all, first time poster. Thought id ask for some honest advice as im having a tough time

Im 23, excelled in high school and had to work labour intensive jobs since to make ends meet. I went to university last year for a bachelor of engineering but had to leave after six months after having a major car crash. I now have a three month old son and a stable construction job that gives good hours. I have the opportunity to start university again next year this time under the honour programme doing the same degree. I desperately want to create a better future for my young family but have massive fears about money due to being raised in poverty.

Do i stay comfortable, work hard and save or dive in to the deep end of full time study and large student loan+side hustle to get by on much less? Dont want to grow old with no skill or profession.

I had good grades last year mostly As and one B.
Earning about 70k/year right now working 60hr weeks
Median salary for a mechanical engineer is 95k here

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27761615
School is irrelevant. Don't confuse it for deserving a job.

Find the job you want, then research it. What are its minimum requirements to apply? Sometimes it'll require a degree, sometimes it will not. What is the income? How far are you willing to move (the further, the more opportunity)?

The idea of going to school because you think it means you'll be successful is a trap. Ask the others caught in the trap.

Find the *JOB* you want, not the degree or the school. Your path will reveal itself that way. And be honest about it. Also research alternative ways of acquiring minimum requirements (military, trade school, etc). There's good jobs out there that require nothing more than a certification.

last_replies.name: Op
last_replies.com:
>>27761722
Do you have any advice for finding the job id like? I really just have a desire to provide for my family and have nice things. My interests have been worn out of me by the necessity of survival. I originally was very interested in becoming an analytical chemist. It then moved to a more design based role in mechanical engineering. I think having a self sustaining business or a mangerial role where I do not have to risk much would bring me the satisfaction and pride I need.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27761808
If you're paraplegic, all you want to do is walk. I do that every day without thinking about it. So if I asked a paraplegic what my goal should be, they'd tell me to walk. I say this because you and I are going to have different goals, different interests, different values. I can't tell you what to like or want.

But I'm sure our overlap is greater than we'd imagine. So, I'll pitch some generic thoughts.

Go to ziprecruiter or indeed or whatever job finding website you use. Search for jobs that interest you. Maybe things in your area, maybe things in areas you'd like to move to.

Scan the qualifications to see what you'd need. Depending on the job, you may be competing with other applicants, so sometimes having a competitive resume helps (particularly for low-qualification/high-earning jobs), sometimes it doesn't matter.

Copy the qualifications and paste them somewhere. That's your professional life checklist now. Assuming you don't currently have the qualifications, the job opening will lapse but another will come around eventually.

Example: Firefighter. Sometimes you'll need Fire 1&2 certificates. Sometimes they'll pick you up off the street with a high school diploma. Sometimes you need to grab EMT certification.

Sometimes they'll pay you 50k, sometimes you'll make 100k. Another trap. That 100k is because the cost of living near these job offers tend to be shit. Keep that in mind. Not universal, but usually.

For job you like: research work hours/schedule, pay, cost-of-living in the area, property taxes in the area, what would give you purpose, benefits, pension, 401k matching, etc.

Don't get too hyped on the *idea* of a job. Think about it in a practical sense. What does a boring day look like and how do you feel about that boring day? You still have drive to do it? Every job becomes just a job over time. I knew Special Operations dudes who thought of their job as just another job. It all becomes normal to you when you do it for a living.

threads.sub: Advice for men
threads.com:
Sharing some advice for men.
My mom didn't let me see my dad until I was 18, so I know how it can be without a male figure.
Thankfully my dad came into the picture when I was 18 and taught me a lot of valuable information that I'd like to share with you all here as I'm now a completely different, much improved older man:

-Stop being bitter about men not being "allowed" to cry.
This is normal for both men and women. Women get more leeway but even women know not to always be a crybaby because it will annoy people.
If you're a man these are the acceptable times to cry: When a loved one or pet dies, the funeral for said loved one or pet, and when you're all by yourself alone, but make sure nobody can hear you.
And happy tears, like you're seeing your wife walk down the aisle towards you.

-It isn't weak to ask for help, but never become dependent on anyone for anything.
It's fine to ask your friend to move for example to make things easier, but don't be dependent on that friend saying yes to be able to move.
This applies to everything in life. Never been dependent as much as possible.
Obviously there's some exceptions like if you're trapped in a car accident and a fireman needs to get you out with the jaws of life. But you get what I mean.

-Even if you're an intellectual you have to workout. Brains won't get you out of everything. You will encounter situations where you HAVE to fight, otherwise you'll lose your dignity. For example, drunk idiot comes and grabs your girlfriend in front of you. That's not a "hey man don't do that" situation, that's a drag that idiot out to the parking lot situation if you ever want your GF to truly respect you.

-Learn how to fight. Goes hand in hand with the previous. Take a practical martial art like boxing, jiu jitsu or krav maga. Don't take fucking taekwondo or karate.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: International Relations or Economics? Which graduation is the best?
threads.com:
Today I have to choose one of the two to pursue a career. I already have some experience with both graduations, but today my option has no turning back.
International Relations seems to be something easier and general, but I have the feeling that I'll finish graduation without any technical knowledge and this scares me, but it may not matter if I get into a public job. Now, Economics is a relatively more closed area and focused on mathematics and analysis (despite having a theoretical area), but I wonder if the work of an economist would be satisfactory, especially in the third sector.
Having these two options and considering stability, possibility of impact in the future and difficulty as objectives (I work, study and spend hours on public transport. I have to consider whether I will have what it takes to have a decent education), which would you choose?
I know the question is kind of boring, but since I need to choose today, it would be good to hear a few words before I make my choice, as it will affect my entire future.

tl;dr; I.R. seems too general and without technical knowledge, Economics seems too difficult. I already have a frenetic routine, but I want to have a good future, what to choose between the two?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27758556
It absolutely does not matter, since only about 25% of grads wind up working in the field of their studies.

Once you get your degree you can apply for ANY job anywhere (except maybe for a few tech fields). They hire the person, not the transcript, and they're going to have to teach you the company way of doing things anyway. A go-getter with no education in the field will be hired ahead of a brain-dead person with the right degree.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>which would you choose?
in IMO.
TLDR: Do Econ as a major and minor in INR. You can pivot to INR career once you get enough experience.

I was in the same shoes as you back a few years ago. I decided to do both. I majored in INR and minored in Econ, but took as many Econ classes as I could (avoiding Econometrics as I know thats brutal.) When I got out of college, I had to leverage my Econ knowledge in interviews more than my INR. Employers don't want to hear about how Fukuyama was wrong in 1992 or the rise of Neorealism. The econ helped me get a bank job for a couple years and I switched to a public INR job still econ related. I have friends of mine who majored in INR fully who are still are underemployed making minimum wage or had to get into PhD program to avoid waging. I suggest taking the Econ route and minoring in INR as it would be more useful and pivoting to the INR career field in the future.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:

>in your late 20s as a friendless male?
you may be in for a rough surprise- when people are in their 30's is when people lose friends. People get on with their lives: in career, family-building, dream-chasing. Some people are just too tired to go out and hang out anymore or some have children to take care of. They're not like they're in their late-teens or twenties anymore.

>how do you make friends
>I'd like to make friends but I've never really had any before
worst way to try to get friends is to try and go out to make friends. Just live your life. Go after your goals. The reason you don't have any friends is because you're not actively "alive." People don't see the drive, the desire, the ambition in you. They don't see that spark, the flame you have because you are trying to reach your best self. Your goals and dreams. Friends come along to help you along the way- they benefit your life by helping you get to where you need to be. That's what friends are. If you aren't even going anywhere, why would anyone stop and try to help you? It would just be a burden to them. In life, people help each other out.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Oneitis
threads.com:
So, this isn't about having a "oneitis".
For those who might not know, "oneitis" is internet slang for when a person (usually a guy) has delusions of 'soulmates' and such to another person (usually a girl) they're in love with. It's the persistent belief that that girl you like (who might be your girlfriend) is "THE ONE", and that even though you might have other things going on for you - career, good friends, hobbies etc - she is a necessary part of your happiness, because she is "special".

I have been there. Had "oneitis" before, I'd even say for more than one girlfriend throughout my life, and it always led me to be "too caring" until they took me for granted and either cheated or it just stopped working.

Now I've been 3 years in with my current girlfriend. She loves me very much, is caring and affectionate, and I strongly believe it's because I never had "oneitis" for her. Don't get me wrong, I like her a lot, but I can't really say I love her deep. After the previous GFs, I don't think I'll ever be deeply in love with anyone anymore.

And here's the dillema: even though not being "too much" in love with my current GF makes her head over heels for me, this doesn't make me truly happy. I wish I could just love her dearly, but years of bad experiences made too jaded to love. And that makes me unhappy. But I'm pretty sure I would lose her if I could love her the way I loved the others. And I'm not even sure if I could even if I tried.

How do I learn to be happy without having to love my SO (and watch her fall apart as a consequence)?
How do the "aloof" guys do?

For me, programming is the next best thing real life has to actual magic. You carefully craft runes in an arcane language to summon the spirit of the machine and bind it to do your bidding.

I'd also agree with >>27757587 that it's a lot closer to math than natural languages. Programming is basically the purest form of applied math. As SICP says very nicely
>Mathematics provides a framework for dealing precisely with notions of “what is.” Computation provides a framework for dealing precisely with notions of “how to.”

It's certainly not for everyone. If math, abstract thinking, or computers do not seem cool and appealing to you, you'll probable be miserable trying to program, so save yourself the pain.

I turn 40 real soon here and have dealt with a lot of what you have in your post (moms death from cancer, bad breakup, shit jobs, too much drinking, etc...)

There really is no easy answer and I do not know how things will or if they will work out for me. Some of us just get dealt a shitty hand in life.

My conclusion that I came to was that I either need to get busy living or get busy dying. I really do not want to die single and in poverty being that lonely pathetic old guy.
Thus, I am going to really try hard to get the things I want (or at least be well on my way to achieving my goals) in the next few years. I am doing everything I can to get /fit/ and become more attractive, I am looking for avenues to make more money, etc...
Basically, its try or die. If after a few years of really working hard and doing my absolute best things still suck I will probably jump a sportbike into the Grand Canyon or something because there is always a time to cut your losses. No point in not trying though because even if you fail you are right back where you started. No opportunity cost in trying for a set amount of time.
I would kill to be 30 again, you have more time than you know. Just remember that the clock is ticking so do not waste your time (especially with alcohol and drugs). You are young enough to build something. I on the other hand might not, it's a 50/50 chance at my age.

Take some time to figure out what you want your life to look like in 10 years and figure out a way to achieve that. You might Suprise yourself.
Best of luck man in whatever you decide.
